message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Cushing’s syndrome, which can be caused by an adrenal tumor. The best initial test for this patient is the overnight dexamethasone suppression test to determine if there is excess cortisol production from the adrenal gland. ACTH stimulation test and inferior petrosal sampling are more helpful if Cushing’s syndrome is suspected to be caused by pituitary gland dysfunction. CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis is less useful since the adrenal nodule has already been identified on prior imaging.

The patient has an adrenal nodule and symptoms of weight gain, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension, which could be due to Cushing's syndrome caused by excess cortisol production. The initial test for Cushing's syndrome is the dexamethasone suppression test. The ACTH stimulation test is used to diagnose Addison's disease or secondary adrenal insufficiency. CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis is used to stage tumors. Inferior petrosal sampling is used in cases of ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome to differentiate between pituitary and ectopic ACTH production.

The 1 mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test is used to differentiate between adrenal adenoma and carcinoma. The test involves administration of dexamethasone orally at bedtime and measurement of cortisol levels in the morning. Adrenal adenoma should suppress cortisol production while carcinoma will not. ACTH stimulation test is used to diagnose adrenal insufficiency, while CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis is used to further evaluate the nodule and identify any metastases. Inferior petrosal sampling is used to diagnose Cushing's syndrome, which is not suggested in this case.
